linkTarget.anchoringText: The Petroleum Company of Trinidad and Tobago is the national oil company with an exploration and production licence to operate the Soldado Fields, its marine asset. This marine asset is managed by Petrotrin Trinmar Operations. The Soldado Fields are is located in the Gulf of Paria, off the south-western peninsula of Trinidad & Tobago, and comprise six fields: Main Soldado, North Soldado, East Soldado, South-West Soldado, West Soldado and Jubilee (Fig-2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Map showing Fields in the Soldado Area operated by Petrotrin Trinmar Operations (Parasram, Jai 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map showing Fields in the Soldado Area operated by Petrotrin Trinmar Operations (Parasram, Jai 2012)

linkTarget.bib:
Parasram, Jai 2012
Jai Parasam. 2012.New oil find in T&T; biggest discovery in 10 years. Jyoti Communication, 3 March 2012, http://jyoticommunication.blogspot.com/2012_03_01_archive.html(accessed 4 April, 2016).

linkTarget.anchoringText: This major obstacle, coupled with repeat workovers (Fig-3 & Fig-4) and unsuccessful completion of heavy workovers (Fig-5) drove the initiative to revise the approach to the company’s well intervention campaigns. Heavy workover candidates were no longer economic to execute and the repeat workovers were quickly increasing the cost of well interventions (Fig-6). Field management meetings with a cross-functional team were re-introduced to identify quick-win initiatives for the wells requiring low-cost investments while the detailed field reviews continued to create a group of wells for reactivation when oil prices allow for economic workovers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: chart showing Repeat Workovers over the last four Fiscal Years

formatted-caption.caption-text: chart showing Repeat Workovers over the last four Fiscal Years

This major obstacle, coupled with repeat workovers (Fig-3 & Fig-4) and unsuccessful completion of heavy workovers (Fig-5) drove the initiative to revise the approach to the company’s well intervention campaigns. Heavy workover candidates were no longer economic to execute and the repeat workovers were quickly increasing the cost of well interventions (Fig-6). Field management meetings with a cross-functional team were re-introduced to identify quick-win initiatives for the wells requiring low-cost investments while the detailed field reviews continued to create a group of wells for reactivation when oil prices allow for economic workovers.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This major obstacle, coupled with repeat workovers (Fig-3 & Fig-4) and unsuccessful completion of heavy workovers (Fig-5) drove the initiative to revise the approach to the company’s well intervention campaigns. Heavy workover candidates were no longer economic to execute and the repeat workovers were quickly increasing the cost of well interventions (Fig-6). Field management meetings with a cross-functional team were re-introduced to identify quick-win initiatives for the wells requiring low-cost investments while the detailed field reviews continued to create a group of wells for reactivation when oil prices allow for economic workovers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Chart showing Cost of Heavy Work over Interventions over the last Four Fiscal Years

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chart showing Cost of Heavy Work over Interventions over the last Four Fiscal Years

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first approach was an evaluation of low-cost activities to reactivate wells. This quick-wins method included low cost rig-less interventions such as coiled tubing clean out (CTCO) campaigns. The CTCO activities showed an increase over the years with a marked increase in 2014 (Fig-7) and a success rate of 85%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Chart showing Number of CTCO Well Interventions

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chart showing Number of CTCO Well Interventions

linkTarget.anchoringText: Though the methodology is not entirely new to Petrotrin (Figs - 8 & 9), it was not aggressively implemented but was applied to the well review process to allow Petrotrin to be better prepared for more favourable oil prices. The previous models omitted the post well analysis subsequent to the well intervention hence the proposal of a more comprehensive model.

linkTarget.bib:
Joseph, 2003
Kevin Joseph . 2003. Proven Performance Improvements in Well Intervention through Outsouring and Continuous Learning Systems. Presented at the SPE Latin American and Caribbean Petroleum engineering Conference, Port of Spain, Trinidad, West Indies, 27-30 April 2003 . SPE 81159-MS http://dx.doi.org/10.2118/81159-MS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Though the methodology is not entirely new to Petrotrin (Figs - 8 & 9), it was not aggressively implemented but was applied to the well review process to allow Petrotrin to be better prepared for more favourable oil prices. The previous models omitted the post well analysis subsequent to the well intervention hence the proposal of a more comprehensive model.
